Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As a result of the Process Hazard Analysis and Off-site Consequence Analysis the following changes were or will be implemented:
¿	Add periodic piping testing per API 570 to PM system. 
¿	Modify monthly tank checklist to inspect signage, bollard and collision protection.
¿	Install wind socks for determining wind direction at 4 corners of site.
¿	Modify Emergency Action Plan to determine wind direction from wind socks and plan evacuation/shelter in place activities based on wind direction.
¿	Update Emergency Action Plan to include the new requirements in 40 CFR 68.90-68.96 including annual emergency response coordination activities and annual notification exercises.

Background

Springdale Energy, LLC is a utility that generates electricity at the Springdale Energy Units 3, 4 & 5 in Springdale Township, Allegheny County, Pennsylvania. In order to reduce NOx air emissions, Springdale installed a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system back in 2002.  This system removes NOx by catalytically reacting NOx with Ammonia to form Nitrogen and water vapor.  The Springdale Energy Springdale facility currently uses aqueous ammonia at a concentration of 29.5%. Back in 2015, the facility changed the concentration of the aqueous ammonia stored at the site and used in the SCR emission control system from 19% to 29.5%, which was the reason for developing this RMP Plan. The process will be applicable to the EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) rules due to the presence of 29.5 % Aqueous Ammonia.

The covered process includes: delivery tank truck unloading, storage, and SCR feed.  The aqueous ammonia storage tank maximum storage capacity is 18,398 gallons (90% capacity).  
 
Overview of the RMP Prevention Program 

The Springdale aqueous ammonia process is considered a Program 2 site by RMP rules.  Springdale uses a management of change and tri-annual compliance audit following EPA requirements.

Process protections are primarily those measures that will reduce, prevent or minimize a release from happening or, if it did happen, minimize the consequences of that threat.    These include:

¿	Procedures and plans such as operational SOPs and the Emergency Response Plan
¿	Training on operations, emergencies etc;
-Operators of the systems covered by the RMP plan have refresher training at least every 3 years.
¿	Regular maintenance/SOPS;        
¿	During deliveries, attendance by the operator and driver are continuous until the delivery is complete;
¿	No ammonia delivery tank trucks stored on site other than those in the process of being unloaded;
¿	Onsite wireless communication;
¿	Onsite trucks/vehicles for emergency transportation
